data.title: Add `build-and-sign` grunt task for codesigning Atom
Not able to set a modul tab length to default if main settings are different
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

I'm not able to set the tab length to the default value (2) in a language modul if I set a value in the main settings tab length,
It immediately changes to the tab length from the main settings.

See also issues Lukasa/language-restructuredtext#37 and atom/language-gfm#134.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set tab length in main settings to 4.
2. Go to the settings of language-html package and set the tab length to 2.
3. It immediately changes to 4.
4. When you leave it empty it shows `Default: 2`. But then also changes to 4. 

It should possible to change the value to the default 2.
Now you can change it to every other value (1,3,5,etc) but not to 2.
### Versions

1.7.2 and 1.8.0-beta2

System: Debian Jessie

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.title: "The editor has crashed"
data.body:
When closing an open folder in the treeview which has other open folders in it, the editor will frequently crash.

**Reproduction Steps:**
1. Open a folder in treeview that has other folders in it.
2. Open one or more of the folders within the first folder.
3. Close and reopen the first folder until the crash.

**Expected behavior:**
Just close the folder, no crash.

**Observed behavior:**
Crash when closing the folder.

**Atom:**
Atom    : 1.7.2
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

**OS and version:**
Windows 10 Pro (version 1511, 64bit)

**Installed packages:**
atom-grails
language-groovy
sort-lines
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: **YES**
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: **YES**
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: **NO**
- Problem happens with all files and projects, not only some files or projects: **YES**

data.title: apm tests fail on latest commit 9ff5fb2
`core:paste` of text copied using `editor:copy-selection` pastes at start of line, instead of cursor.
data.body:
### Background

Hi, pressing ctrl-c on an empty line, copies the whole line.  Which is fine, except it deletes what's on the clipboard which is incredibly annoying.  I'd select the line if I wanted it.

A work-around, from this merge: https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/8025
and described here: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7103
is to use this in keymap.cson:

```
'atom-text-editor':
  'ctrl-c': 'editor:copy-selection'    # linux and windows
```

But unfortunately that pastes at the start of the line, instead of the cursor.  I'm using Atom 1.5.3 on Ubuntu 14.04.

Thanks!
### Steps to Reproduce
1.  Edit -> Preferences -> keybindings -> tiny link at top: 'your keymap file'
2.  paste above code
3. Save `keymap.cson`
4.  Open file.  Select some text in middle of line.  ctrl-c
5.  Ctrl-v and it's pasted at start of line.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

pasted at cursor

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

pasted at start of line
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom 1.5.3 on Ubuntu 14.04

data.title: :memo: [ci skip] add notes on 'apm' path in Windows
data.body: Comments came out while discussing issue #11137

data.title: Bring back single click to open a file
data.body:
I used to be able to single click a file in the file tree to open it. Now there's the "Allow Pending Pane Items" setting. When turned on, a single click opens the file in a preview tab. When turned off, a single click does nothing. I don't like using the preview feature, but I also don't like needing to double click a file to open it. Can you bring back the single click to open a file when the preview option is turned off?

Using Atom 1.7.2

data.title: 🏇 Improve perf for clicking below buffer of long line to seek cursor
data.body:
In cases where the last line of a file is very long and the user clicks below that line to seek to the end of the last line, it can take a very long time due to calculating the position of every single column. See #10769 for a test case.

This commit checks the special case of clicking below the buffer and returns the position without going into the whole calculation loop. I'm not super familiar with how the internals of Atom work, and I assumed going through all this calculation to find the very last cursor position was needed due to surrogate pairs or something. But it seems that's not the case as the last column position can be found by just summing the row's textNode lengths, so short circuiting that logic brings a perf win.

This stops freezing for clicking below long lines, but doesn't solve the whole perf problem with seeking long lines. If you were to scroll to the end of a long line and click somewhere close to the end, it will still hang. Perhaps you could calculate the position backwards if the click position is in the latter half of the long line? Either way, that's a discussion for another issue/PR.

As far as tests go, I'm not really sure how you run the line-yardstick specs? Running `script/test` had a lot of failures on master for other specs. I don't think any new specs for line-yardstick is required since it already covers testing clicking below the buffer.

Resolves #10769

data.title: Repeatedly collapsing/expanding folders in tree-view crashes the editor
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

### Description

![tree_view_crash](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1017132/14666823/59fc31c8-06e4-11e6-8c6f-75b838c87fa1.gif)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a project with at least two nested folders inside the project
2. Expand the two nested folders
3. Start rapidly and repeatedly collapsing/expanding the outer folder of the two

**Expected behavior:** Folders would expand/collapse

**Actual behavior:** Editor crashes
### Versions

Running Windows 10 with latest Atom beta

```
Atom    : 1.8.0-beta2
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

data.title: Add Project::createFile and ::createDirectory
data.body:
This PR implements four new methods on `Project` to create files, create directories, and watch for the creation of both:
- `Project::createFile(path)`
- `Project::createDirectory(path)`
- `Project::onDidCreateFile(callback)`
- `Project::onDidCreateDirectory(callback)`

Currently packages (like `tree-view`) manually call out to the filesystem APIs to create files, and other packages aren't notified of such changes. This leads to bugs like https://github.com/atom/fuzzy-finder/issues/175. By centralizing file and directory creation and adding notification hooks, packages can be notified any time a `Project`'s file structure changes.

/cc @nathansobo @atom/core

data.body:
### Description

`pane:show` would list a bunch of keybindings.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/14660893/47c1f5b4-0677-11e6-82f3-1016278395ba.png)

`pane show` shows none.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/14660899/540c2358-0677-11e6-8d1d-9d449fc9556f.png)
### Steps to Reproduce

Open Keybindings, type in `pane show`.

**Expected behavior:** Shows all keybindings that have a command including the word `pane` and `show`.
Basically a word-wise fuzzy match.

**Actual behavior:** Search returns no result.
### Versions

OS X 10.11.4
Atom 1.7.2

I can work on this and make a PR.

data.title: [Feature Request] When pressing Ctrl-Tab key, display a panel of tab list in MRU order for cycling
data.body:
### Description

The MRU tab switching in 1.7 is great, however it would be even better to pop up a tabs list panel in MRU order when pressing `ctrl-tab`, so that I can choose which specific tab to go to by holding `ctrl` and pressing `tab` key. The current behaviour would just jump to the first tab in the MRU stack, which is fine but really doesn't cover the most of editing scenarios.

What I mean is something like this package does [enhanced-tabs](https://atom.io/packages/enhanced-tabs).

Thanks!
### Versions

OS X: 10.10
Atom: 1.7.2

data.title: Update languages
data.body:
Putting these updates into a PR to make sure nothing breaks and to give CI a break :P.

Summary of changes:
- language-coffee-script
  - Fix incorrect scopes on whitespace
  - Fix duplicate scopes on some assignment variables
- language-java
  - Tokenize all the punctuation!
  - Tokenize generics
- language-sass
  - SASS: Properly tokenize comments
  - SCSS: Don't tokenize URLs as comments
- language-yaml
  - Tokenize `true`, `false`, and `null` as language constants

And more to come soon hopefully!

Will merge once :green_apple:.

data.title: Build instructions for openSUSE uses missing dependency
data.body:
### Description

The build instructions for openSUSE shows install `rpmdevtools` with `zypper`, but no such stable package exists.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Boot openSUSE.
2. `sudo zypper install rpmdevtools`

**Actual behavior:**

``` bash
Loading repository data...
Reading installed packages...
'rpmdevtools' not found in package names. Trying capabilities.
No provider of 'rpmdevtools' found.
Resolving package dependencies...

Nothing to do.
```

**Expected behavior:**

Instructions for adding user repos (or something stable?):

``` bash
sudo zypper addrepo -f http://download.opensuse.org/repositories/devel:/tools/openSUSE_Factory_ARM/ devel:tools
sudo zypper addrepo -f http://download.opensuse.org/repositories/systemsmanagement:/wbem:/deps/openSUSE_Factory/ systemsmanagement:wbem:deps
sudo zypper update
sudo zypper install rpmdevtools
```


data.title: Atom Unusable on Windows - Heavy Lag
data.body:
### Description

Atom has begun to run at a snails pace, with ~5 latency between actions spaced out over a ~20 second interval. As in, it will run smoothly for ~ 20 seconds before locking up from an action for ~5 seconds. This happens consistently throughout any open document. The number of open tabs doesn't matter. Safe mode changed nothing, removing/disabling plugins changed nothing, attempting to completely uninstall & reinstall Atom changed nothing. 

Running out of troubleshooting options to try, as I think I've attempted everything to resolve the issue. I ran a CPU profile through dev tools, see attached .zip file. 

[CPU-Profile.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/226490/CPU-Profile.zip)

In this state, the software is unusable, and has put a large fork in my workflow.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Launch Atom
2. Observe Lag

**Expected behavior:**
No Lag

**Actual behavior:**
Insane Lag
### Versions

```
Atom     : 1.7.2
Electron : 0.36.8
Chrome   : 47.9.2526.110
Node     : 5.1.1

```

```
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.13
node 0.10.40
git 1.9.5.github.0
```

```
Windows 10 Pro
Version  : 1511
OS Build : 10586.218
```

data.title: Atom on Windows seems to get confused about update availability
data.body:
Summary: Sometimes Atom gets confused when there is an Atom update--it indicates an update is available via squirrel icon in status bar, but when I try to update it says no update is available.

Longer version: According to the Help menu, I have 1.7.1 installed. The squirrel icon is displayed in the status bar. If I click the icon, a pane opens and displays a message that "Atom is update to date!" and shows version 1.7.1 at the top of the pane under the Atom logo. Automatically download updates is selected. If I click  "Check Now" an alert appears and says "no update available" and "Version 1.7.1 is the latest version." If I go to the Help menu and select "check for update" I get the same alert. When going to https://atom.io/docs, I see it reports the most recent version is 1.7.2. So, it seems that somehow the status bar knows there is an update available even though the rest of Atom doesn't.

If I restart Atom, it will update to 1.7.2 (this has happened to me quite a few times in the past, pretty much with every update that gets released). Atom will function normally (no squirrel icon) until the next update is released, at which time I expect that I'll see this issue again.

I see an app-1.7.1 and app-1.7.2 in my AppData/Local/atom folder.

OS: Windows 10, version 1511 build 10586.218
atom.exe --version (from app-1.7.1 directory; running atom --version from path returns no output) returns:
  Atom    : 1.7.1
  Electron: 0.36.8
  Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
  Node    : 5.1.1

apm --version returns:
  apm  1.9.2
  npm  2.13.3
  node 0.10.40
  python 2.7.9
  git 2.7.1.windows.2
  visual studio

data.title: At the building stage, Running "download-electron" task ends with an error
data.body:
Atom v1.7.2
Node: v4.4.3
npm: v2.13.3
Linux Mint 17.3 Rosa (Linux version 3.13.0-24-generic)

At the building stage (script/build), the script ends at the following task with an error:

`Running "download-electron" task`
`Fatal error: Request path contains unescaped characters.`

`TypeError: Request path contains unescaped characters.`
 `at new ClientRequest (_http_client.js:50:11)`
`at TunnelingAgent.exports.request (http.js:31:10)`
`at TunnelingAgent.createSocket (/home/usr/Downloads/atom/build/node_modules/request/node_modules/tunnel-agent/index.js:117:25)`
`at TunnelingAgent.createSecureSocket [as createSocket] (/home/usr/Downloads/atom/build/node_modules/request/node_modules/tunnel-agent/index.js:184:41)`
 `at TunnelingAgent.addRequest (/home/usr/Downloads/atom/build/node_modules/request/node_modules/tunnel-agent/index.js:80:8)`
`at new ClientRequest (_http_client.js:131:16)`
`at Object.exports.request (http.js:31:10)`
`at Object.socket.once.exports.request (https.js:182:15)`
`at Request.start (/home/usr/Downloads/atom/build/node_modules/request/request.js:585:30)`
`at Request.end (/home/usr/Downloads/atom/build/node_modules/request/request.js:1213:28)`
`at /home/usr/Downloads/atom/build/node_modules/request/request.js:417:12`
`at nextTickCallbackWith0Args (node.js:420:9)`
`at process._tickDomainCallback (node.js:390:13)`
`at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:443:11)`
`at startup (node.js:139:18)`
`at node.js:968:3`

This error occurs only if I set environment variables `http_proxy` or `https_proxy`. If I unset this variables I get a following error because I am behind proxy:

`Cannot find electron v0.36.8 from GitHub { [Error: connect ECONNREFUSED 192.30.252.124:443]`
 `code: 'ECONNREFUSED',`
 `errno: 'ECONNREFUSED',`
 `syscall: 'connect',`
 `address: '192.30.252.124',`
 `port: 443 }`
`Warning: Task "download-electron" failed. Use --force to continue.`

My `http_proxy` variable looks like this:

`http_proxy=http://192.168.22.9:3128/`

Evidently, there is no characters that should be escaped.

There is a comment in ClientRequest function,  in_http_client.js,  Node.js source code that says:

`// The actual regex is more like /[^A-Za-z0-9\-._~!$&'()*+,;=/:@]/`
  `// with an additional rule for ignoring percentage-escaped characters`
 `// but that's a) hard to capture in a regular expression that performs`
 `// well, and b) possibly too restrictive for real-world usage. That's`
  `// why it only scans for spaces because those are guaranteed to create`
 `// an invalid request.`

So perhaps the problem is that some space characters are inserted in proxy url by mistake but I cannot find out where it may happens in Atom source code.

data.title: Files opened without content and with repetitive tabs for the same file.
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Files are opened empty for period of time and some of them are repetitive. It is happening since couple of versions, but can't say since which one exactly.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Double click a file to open.
2. Fast another one

**Expected behavior:**
To open the file with content and to have only one tab per file, not double.

**Actual behavior:**
Files are opened without content. After some time, the file content is appearing and just after it, last file or randomly (can't say) is opened in separate tab.
### Versions

OS: Mac OS X 10.11.4

data.title: Blinking scrollbars/soft wrap
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

When certain text is entered in the editor with "soft wrap" enabled, sometimes the editor cannot decide on which word to wrap and just alternates between the two options, which is extremely distracting.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Enter some text
2. (after some time/luck) Observe blinking scrollbars

**Expected behavior:** Nothing moves unless I edit something

**Actual behavior:** See the video attachment
[blink.ogv.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/225726/blink.ogv.zip)
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.7.2
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.5.0
```

I'm running Ubuntu 15.10 with Gnome Shell 3.16

data.title: keyboard shortcuts not showing in menus (Ubuntu 16.04)
data.body:
### Prerequisites

Ubuntu 16.04
Atom 1.7.2
### Description

Window drop down menues are not showing the keyboard shortcuts (ctr-f, etc.) after upgrade to Ubuntu 16.04.

This is probably a Chromium/Electron/GTK issue as they are not showing in Chrome as well. But it might be worth tracking this issues here if someone comes up with a workaround.

data.title: the atom clean the all content of my files which has been saved in early
data.body:
I am very disappointed with this software!
because when I exit the atom, it clean  all content of my files which has been saved early and make my work result loss. Moreover, it doesn't  prompt me for unsaved file when I exit it.

data.title: Starting Atom: Uncaught RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
data.body:
I get this error everytime I start Atom if there is a tab open in the list that Atom wants to reopen, if there is not a tab open when starting Atom, everything is fine.. 

This issue has been since v. 1.7.0

I run Windows 10

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

[Description of the bug or feature]
### Steps to Reproduce
1. [First Step]
2. [Second Step]
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.title: Finder slow to show results
data.body:
### Description
- Typing `cmd+k`  produces the finder window
- Since the 1.7.1 update the results window has a slight delay in displaying the results

[Description of the bug or feature]
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Type `CMD+K`
2. wait

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
- should display results instantaneously 

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
- results show after around .5 delay
### Versions

1.7.1
![finder](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5571736/14621057/16a2f184-0575-11e6-8eaa-7241985f5ddf.gif)
